news_summary: Advancements in space exploration are progressing with innovative developments in spacewalking technology for the Artemis missions and new insights into the Sagittarius B2 molecular cloud.
news_summary_fr: L'exploration spatiale progresse grâce à des développements novateurs dans la technologie des sorties dans l'espace pour les missions Artemis et à de nouvelles connaissances sur le nuage moléculaire Sagittarius B2.
news_summary_es: Los avances en la exploración espacial progresan con innovaciones en la tecnología de los paseos espaciales para las misiones Artemis y nuevos conocimientos sobre la nube molecular B2 de Sagitario.

articles.title: Mark Elder: Building the Future of Spacewalking for Artemis and Beyond
articles.summary: For more than 25 years, Mark Elder has helped make human spaceflight safe and possible. As the International Space Station EVA hardware manager in the Extravehicular Activity (EVA) Office within the EVA and Human Surface Mobility Program, he leads the team responsible for the spacesuits, tools, and logistics that keep astronauts protected during spacewalks—and ensures […]
articles.content:
For more than 25 years, Mark Elder has helped make human spaceflight safe and possible. As the International Space Station EVA hardware manager in the Extravehicular Activity (EVA) Office within the EVA and Human Surface Mobility Program, he leads the team responsible for the spacesuits, tools, and logistics that keep astronauts protected during spacewalks—and ensures NASA is ready for the next era of Artemis exploration.

Mark Elder with NASA’s Exploration Extravehicular Mobility Unit (xEMU) spacesuit at Johnson Space Center in Houston. NASA/Bill Stafford

His team is programmatically responsible for the Extravehicular Mobility Unit, or EMU, spacesuit. That means every bolt, bearing, and battery astronauts rely on outside the International Space Station ultimately falls under their watch. He also oversees the EVA Space Operations Contract, which provides engineering and technical support to keep spacesuit systems flight ready.

Elder’s work directly supports every EVA, or spacewalk, conducted at the station. His team coordinates with astronauts, engineers, and the Mission Control Center in Houston to make sure the suits and tools operate reliably in the most unforgiving environment imaginable. Their work helps ensure every EVA is conducted safely and successfully.

Elder’s passion for NASA began at an early age.

“When I was little, my parents gave me a book called ‘The Astronauts,’” he said. “It had drawings of a reusable spacecraft—the space shuttle—and I fell in love with it. From then on, I told everyone I was going to work at NASA.”

That dream took off at age 16, when he attended Space Academy in Huntsville, Alabama. “That cemented my dream of someday working at NASA, and it taught me a little bit more about the different roles within the agency,” he said.

While attending Case Western Reserve University as a mechanical engineering student, he learned about a new NASA program that allowed college students to design and build an experiment and then come to Johnson Space Center for a week to fly with their experiment on the Boeing KC-135 Stratotanker. “I jumped on the chance to be part of the team,” he said. “The experience further cemented my dream of working at NASA one day—Johnson in particular.”

After graduation, Elder worked with Pratt & Whitney on jet engines. While the experience was invaluable, he knew his heart belonged in human spaceflight. “I learned that one of Pratt’s fellow companies under the United Technologies umbrella was Hamilton Sundstrand, which was the prime contractor for the spacesuit,” he said. “I jumped at the chance to transfer, and my career at NASA finally began.”

Elder spent his first three years at Johnson performing tool-to-tool fit checks on spacewalking equipment, giving him hands-on experience with nearly every tool that he would eventually become responsible for as a hardware manager.

Mark Elder stands in front of the Space Shuttle Atlantis before the STS-117 launch on June 8, 2007.

His early years coincided with the shuttle return-to-flight era, when he worked on reinforced carbon-carbon panel repairs and thermal protection systems. Those experiences built his technical foundation and prepared him for the leadership roles to come.

Over time, Elder took on increasingly complex assignments, eventually leading the team that developed the EVA Long Life Battery—the first human-rated lithium battery used in space. His team created a rigorous test plan to certify the battery for human spaceflight at a time when lithium batteries were under scrutiny for safety concerns.

“Finally signing the certification paperwork was satisfying, but watching an EVA powered by the batteries provided a great sense of pride,” he said.

This innovation set the stage for future generations of even safer, higher-capacity batteries that power today’s spacewalking operations and will eventually support lunar surface activities.

Looking back, Elder said some of his greatest lessons came from learning how to lead with purpose. “The great thing about NASA is the highly motivated and dedicated workforce,” he said. “When I first became a team lead, I thought success meant making quick decisions and moving fast. I learned that leadership is really about listening. Strong teams are built on trust and open communication.”

Another defining lesson, he said, has been learning to assume positive intent. “In a place like NASA, everyone is deeply passionate about what they do,” he said. “It’s easy to misinterpret a disagreement as opposition, but when you remember that everyone is working toward the same goal, the conversation changes. You focus on solving problems, not winning arguments.”

That mindset has guided Elder through some of NASA’s most complex programs and helped him build lasting partnerships across the agency.

Mark Elder receives an award at the 2024 Rotary National Award for Space Achievement Stellar Awards ceremony at the Hyatt Regency in downtown Houston. NASA/Josh Valcarcel

Today, Elder’s work extends beyond the orbiting laboratory. As NASA prepares for Artemis missions to the Moon, his team’s experience maintaining and improving the EMU informs the design of next-generation exploration suits.

“The foundation we’ve built on the space station is critical for the future,” he said. “Every tool we’ve refined, every system we’ve upgraded—it all feeds into how we’ll operate on the lunar surface and eventually on Mars.”

Elder believes that the key to future success lies in perseverance. He advises the next generation to never stop dreaming. “My path wasn’t direct, and it would have been easy for me to give up,” he said. “But dreams have a way of guiding you if you don’t let go of them.”

When he’s not supporting those missions, Elder’s creativity takes shape in his workshop. “In my spare time, I love woodworking,” he said. “Building something useful from a pile of rough-sawn boards helps calm me and gives me a great sense of accomplishment. I love being able to build furniture for my family,” he added, after recently finishing a desk for his youngest son.

The same patience and precision he brings to woodworking defines his approach to exploration—steady progress, careful craftmanship, and attention to detail. “As NASA goes to the Moon and Mars, there will be challenges,” Elder said. “As long as we keep dreaming, we will see the next generation walking on the Moon and heading to Mars.”
articles.reasoning: The article highlights Mark Elder's significant contributions to human spaceflight safety and the development of spacesuit technology, which directly supports current and future space exploration missions like Artemis. It details tangible advancements such as the EVA Long Life Battery and the preparation for lunar and Mars exploration, demonstrating broad and meaningful impact on space exploration and human presence beyond Earth.
articles.personality_title: Mark Elder shapes the future of spacewalking for NASA’s Artemis missions
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Mark Elder has spent over 25 years working to make spacewalks safe for astronauts aboard the International Space Station (ISS). He leads a team that manages the spacesuits, tools, and support systems needed for astronauts to work outside the station.

**What happened** – Elder’s team is responsible for the Extravehicular Mobility Unit (EMU), the special spacesuit astronauts wear during spacewalks. They ensure every part of the suit and all the tools are ready and safe. Elder also helped develop the EVA Long Life Battery, the first lithium battery certified for use in spacewalks, improving suit power and safety. His work now supports NASA’s Artemis program, which plans to send astronauts back to the Moon and eventually to Mars.

**Impact** – Elder’s decades of experience have helped keep astronauts safe during spacewalks and have improved the technology that will be used on future missions to the Moon and Mars. The new spacesuit designs and tools he helps create build on the lessons learned from the ISS, making space exploration safer and more reliable.

**What’s next step** – Elder’s team will continue refining spacesuits and tools for Artemis missions. This includes preparing for longer and more challenging spacewalks on the Moon’s surface and, later, on Mars. Their work will help astronauts explore new worlds with better protection and equipment.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Mark Elder’s leadership in spacesuit technology is key to keeping astronauts safe during spacewalks today and enabling future exploration of the Moon and Mars.
articles.personality_title_fr: Mark Elder façonne l’avenir des sorties dans l’espace pour les missions Artemis
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Mark Elder travaille depuis plus de 25 ans à sécuriser les sorties dans l’espace pour les astronautes à bord de la Station spatiale internationale (ISS). Il dirige une équipe qui gère les combinaisons spatiales, les outils et les systèmes de soutien nécessaires aux astronautes pour travailler à l’extérieur de la station.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – L’équipe d’Elder est responsable de l’Unité de Mobilité Extravehiculaire (EMU), la combinaison spéciale portée par les astronautes lors des sorties dans l’espace. Ils veillent à ce que chaque pièce de la combinaison et tous les outils soient prêts et sûrs. Elder a également aidé à développer la batterie longue durée EVA, la première batterie lithium certifiée pour une utilisation lors des sorties spatiales, améliorant ainsi l’autonomie et la sécurité. Son travail soutient aujourd’hui le programme Artemis de la NASA, qui prévoit de renvoyer des astronautes sur la Lune puis sur Mars.

**Impact** – Les décennies d’expérience d’Elder ont permis de protéger les astronautes lors des sorties dans l’espace et d’améliorer la technologie qui sera utilisée lors des futures missions sur la Lune et Mars. Les nouveaux modèles de combinaisons et outils qu’il aide à créer s’appuient sur les leçons tirées de l’ISS, rendant l’exploration spatiale plus sûre et plus fiable.

**Prochaine étape** – L’équipe d’Elder va continuer à perfectionner les combinaisons et outils pour les missions Artemis. Cela inclut la préparation de sorties plus longues et plus difficiles à la surface de la Lune, puis sur Mars. Leur travail aidera les astronautes à explorer de nouveaux mondes avec une meilleure protection et de meilleurs équipements.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le leadership de Mark Elder dans la technologie des combinaisons spatiales est essentiel pour la sécurité des astronautes lors des sorties spatiales aujourd’hui et pour permettre l’exploration future de la Lune et de Mars.
articles.personality_title_es: Mark Elder impulsa el futuro de las caminatas espaciales para las misiones Artemis
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Mark Elder ha trabajado por más de 25 años para hacer seguras las caminatas espaciales de los astronautas en la Estación Espacial Internacional (EEI). Dirige un equipo que gestiona los trajes espaciales, las herramientas y los sistemas de apoyo necesarios para que los astronautas trabajen fuera de la estación.

**Qué pasó** – El equipo de Elder es responsable de la Unidad de Movilidad Extravehicular (EMU), el traje especial que usan los astronautas durante las caminatas espaciales. Se aseguran de que cada parte del traje y todas las herramientas estén listas y seguras. Elder también ayudó a desarrollar la Batería de Larga Vida EVA, la primera batería de litio certificada para usarse en caminatas espaciales, mejorando la energía y la seguridad del traje. Su trabajo ahora apoya el programa Artemis de la NASA, que planea enviar astronautas a la Luna y luego a Marte.

**Impacto** – La experiencia de décadas de Elder ha ayudado a mantener seguros a los astronautas durante las caminatas espaciales y ha mejorado la tecnología que se usará en futuras misiones a la Luna y Marte. Los nuevos diseños de trajes y herramientas que ayuda a crear se basan en las lecciones aprendidas en la EEI, haciendo que la exploración espacial sea más segura y confiable.

**Próximo paso** – El equipo de Elder seguirá mejorando los trajes y herramientas para las misiones Artemis. Esto incluye prepararse para caminatas espaciales más largas y difíciles en la superficie lunar y, después, en Marte. Su trabajo ayudará a los astronautas a explorar nuevos mundos con mejor protección y equipo.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El liderazgo de Mark Elder en tecnología de trajes espaciales es clave para mantener a los astronautas seguros hoy y para permitir la exploración futura de la Luna y Marte.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a sturdy, intricately crafted spacesuit gently resting on a wooden workbench surrounded by hand tools and mechanical parts, symbolizing careful craftsmanship and innovation, set against a softly glowing backdrop of the Moon’s surface blending into a starry sky, representing the bridge between Earth-based preparation and future lunar exploration.

articles.title: Sagittarius B2 Molecular Cloud
articles.summary: The Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI) on NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope captured glowing cosmic dust heated by very young massive stars in unprecedented detail in this image of the Sagittarius B2 (Sgr B2) molecular cloud released on Sept. 24, 2025. Sgr B2 is the most massive, and active star-forming region in our galaxy, located only a […]
articles.content:
NASA, ESA, CSA, STScI, Adam Ginsburg (University of Florida), Nazar Budaiev (University of Florida), Taehwa Yoo (University of Florida); Image Processing: Alyssa Pagan (STScI)

The Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI) on NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope captured glowing cosmic dust heated by very young massive stars in unprecedented detail in this image of the Sagittarius B2 (Sgr B2) molecular cloud released on Sept. 24, 2025.

Sgr B2 is the most massive, and active star-forming region in our galaxy, located only a few hundred light years from our central supermassive black hole. While Sgr B2 has only 10% of the galactic center’s gas, it produces 50% of its stars. Astronomers want to figure out why it is so much more active than the rest of the galactic center.

MIRI has both a camera and a spectrograph that sees light in the mid-infrared region of the electromagnetic spectrum. MIRI’s view reveals colorful stars punctuated occasionally by bright clouds of gas and dust. Further research into these stars will reveal details of their masses and ages, which will help astronomers better understand the process of star formation in this dense, active galactic center region.

Image credit: Image: NASA, ESA, CSA, STScI, Adam Ginsburg (University of Florida), Nazar Budaiev (University of Florida), Taehwa Yoo (University of Florida); Image Processing: Alyssa Pagan (STScI)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific achievement: the James Webb Space Telescope's Mid-Infrared Instrument capturing unprecedented detailed images of the Sagittarius B2 molecular cloud, a key star-forming region in our galaxy. This discovery advances understanding of star formation processes in a major galactic region, representing a meaningful breakthrough in space science with broad implications for astronomy.
articles.personality_title: James Webb Telescope reveals detailed view of star birth in Sagittarius B2 cloud
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Sagittarius B2 (Sgr B2) is a huge cloud of gas and dust near the center of our Milky Way galaxy. It is the most active place in the galaxy where new stars are born, producing half of the stars in that central area, even though it has only a small part of the gas.

**What happened** – On September 24, 2025, NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope used its Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI) to capture a detailed image of glowing dust heated by very young, massive stars inside Sgr B2. This instrument sees light that our eyes cannot, revealing colorful stars and bright clouds of gas and dust in great detail.

**Impact** – This is the clearest picture ever taken of this star-forming cloud. It helps scientists study how stars form in one of the busiest star nurseries in our galaxy. Understanding why Sgr B2 is more active than other parts of the galaxy’s center could explain how stars develop in dense, busy space environments.

**What’s next step** – Scientists will analyze the light from these stars to learn their sizes and ages. This information will help them understand the star formation process better and could lead to new discoveries about how galaxies grow and change.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The James Webb Telescope’s new detailed image of Sagittarius B2 offers fresh insights into how stars are born in one of the galaxy’s busiest stellar nurseries.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le télescope James Webb révèle une vue détaillée de la naissance des étoiles dans le nuage Sagittarius B2
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Sagittarius B2 (Sgr B2) est un immense nuage de gaz et de poussière près du centre de notre galaxie, la Voie lactée. C’est l’endroit le plus actif de la galaxie où naissent de nouvelles étoiles, produisant la moitié des étoiles dans cette zone centrale, bien qu’il contienne seulement une petite partie du gaz.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 24 septembre 2025, le télescope spatial James Webb de la NASA a utilisé son instrument Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI) pour capturer une image détaillée de la poussière brillante chauffée par des étoiles très jeunes et massives à l’intérieur de Sgr B2. Cet instrument capte une lumière invisible à l’œil nu, montrant des étoiles colorées et des nuages lumineux de gaz et de poussière avec beaucoup de détails.

**Impact** – C’est l’image la plus claire jamais prise de ce nuage formant des étoiles. Elle aide les scientifiques à étudier comment les étoiles se forment dans l’un des lieux de naissance d’étoiles les plus actifs de notre galaxie. Comprendre pourquoi Sgr B2 est plus actif que d’autres zones du centre galactique pourrait expliquer comment les étoiles se développent dans des environnements spatiaux denses et animés.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques analyseront la lumière de ces étoiles pour connaître leur taille et leur âge. Ces informations leur permettront de mieux comprendre le processus de formation des étoiles et pourraient conduire à de nouvelles découvertes sur la croissance et l’évolution des galaxies.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – La nouvelle image détaillée de Sagittarius B2 prise par le télescope James Webb offre de nouvelles clés pour comprendre la naissance des étoiles dans l’un des pouponnières stellaires les plus actifs de la galaxie.
articles.personality_title_es: El telescopio James Webb revela una vista detallada del nacimiento de estrellas en la nube Sagittarius B2
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Sagittarius B2 (Sgr B2) es una enorme nube de gas y polvo cerca del centro de nuestra galaxia, la Vía Láctea. Es el lugar más activo de la galaxia donde nacen nuevas estrellas, produciendo la mitad de las estrellas en esa área central, aunque contiene solo una pequeña parte del gas.

**Qué pasó** – El 24 de septiembre de 2025, el telescopio espacial James Webb de la NASA usó su instrumento Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI) para capturar una imagen detallada del polvo brillante calentado por estrellas muy jóvenes y masivas dentro de Sgr B2. Este instrumento ve luz que no podemos ver con nuestros ojos, mostrando estrellas coloridas y brillantes nubes de gas y polvo con mucho detalle.

**Impacto** – Esta es la imagen más clara jamás tomada de esta nube formadora de estrellas. Ayuda a los científicos a estudiar cómo se forman las estrellas en uno de los lugares más activos para el nacimiento de estrellas en nuestra galaxia. Entender por qué Sgr B2 es más activo que otras partes del centro galáctico podría explicar cómo se desarrollan las estrellas en ambientes espaciales densos y ocupados.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos analizarán la luz de estas estrellas para conocer su tamaño y edad. Esta información les ayudará a entender mejor el proceso de formación estelar y podría llevar a nuevos descubrimientos sobre cómo crecen y cambian las galaxias.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La nueva imagen detallada de Sagittarius B2 del telescopio James Webb ofrece nuevas ideas sobre cómo nacen las estrellas en uno de los viveros estelares más activos de la galaxia.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a vast cosmic nebula glowing with swirling clouds of vibrant mid-infrared dust and gas, illuminated by clusters of radiant, young massive stars represented as bright, softly pulsating orbs nestled within the dense Sagittarius B2 molecular cloud near a subtle, abstract silhouette of a galactic center’s dark core.
